title.narrative: Obligation to Protect (O2P) Kenya - Agents of change unite against FGM/C

description.narrative: A flyer explaining the programme in Kenya and the other three countries in which it is being implemented was distributed, including background information about Plan and AWEPA. The flyer was distributed during events, such as Zero Tolerance Day 2014, The Lifting the Veil expert meeting 2015 and the 2015 “Afrika Dag”.

By changing social norms, this project is driving a permanent change in the way people see FGM/C. Once social norms in a community change, that change is usually irreversible, meaning that, thanks to this project, FGM/C prevalence rates will continue to drop after it has ended.
By connecting and strengthening local organisations, youth groups and women groups, the project is installing structures that will remain in place after its completion. These organisations are acting in networks to jointly influence change at county and national levels. Furthermore, by creating safe spaces for girls and young women they will be able to discuss their problems and get the support they need to claim their rights.
The project is also strengthening the linkages between the various types of change makers. This will improve cooperation in stopping FGM/C and give girls and young women access to important actors at local, state/district and even national levels.

Defending human rights and using parliamentarians in Kenya is taking more time and effort than was expected. Both girls and boys are being trained as agents of change, but more efforts will be needed if they are to become the defenders of human rights. These are lessons we would like to explore in more detail in the mid-term review (MTR) of this project.

FGM/C is a violation of human rights and an extreme form of violence and discrimination against girls and women. It involves the partial or total removal of the external female genitalia or other types of injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons. It is viewed as a traditional practice, despite it being very painful and risky for the health of girls and women. It can also cause many complications during menstruation, pregnancy and childbirth, and can even sometimes result in death. Although FGM/C is against the law in Kenya, in rural areas of the country there are insufficient resources and support to enforce the law. Furthermore, the infrastructure to protect girls and boys from violence is weak. In Kenya as a whole, 27.1 per cent of women are subjected to FMG/C, but this percentage is higher among certain tribes and ethnic groups. In Tharaka-Nithi county 58 per cent of girls between the ages of 7 and 17 are subjected to it. The practice is deeply rooted in the local society and is usually carried out by family or community members. They see FGM/C as a necessary step towards social acceptance and as a rite of passage for girls.

In Kenya the UNICEF/UNFPA joint programme against FGM/C is strengthening the structure of the government at both national and regional levels. This project also works at community level and targets groups that are not yet covered by the above-mentioned initiatives, namely: girls, boys and local organisations and parliamentarians. In addition to all this, the project complements existing Plan projects, making it possible to build on earlier successes, such as working with previously trained stakeholders and community structures.

In the first year of the project 1,300 T-shirts with anti-FGM/C sentiments were produced by Plan and the National Anti-FGM board. They were distributed during the International Day Of The Girl Child, 16 Days Of Activism and the Plan and Anti-FGM Board county campaign.

SUMMARY Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting (FGM/C) is an extreme form of violence against girls and women. This project, which is being carried out by Plan and its partner, Association of European Parliamentarians with Africa (AWEPA), aims to eradicate this practice within a generation in selected communities in Tharaka-Nithi county, Kenya. To underscore the kind of optimum outcomes that will be crucial for the permanent eradication of FMG/C the project is being carried out at individual, community and institutional levels. It teaches communities about girls’ rights and that FGM/C is illegal. It also encourages local organisations like youth and women’s groups to challenge norms and attitudes and it supports parliamentarians in implementing effective legislation. This four-year project started in January 2014 and is part of a bigger programme that is being carried out in four countries (Egypt, Sudan, Kenya and Ethiopia).

Some 45,000 girls and 50,000 boys between the ages of 10 and 18 in Tharaka-Nithi county will benefit from this project. The girls have been identified by Plan as being vulnerable to FGM/C. The boys are also important because they are seen as the defenders and future guardians of the changed social norms and the eradication of FGM/C.

The project was supported by two TV documentaries and a live talk-show interview that was broadcast by three Kenyan TV stations (K24, QTV and NTV). The link below shows how awareness is being increased among Kenyans that the government and other stakeholders must do more to combat FGM/C.
